reviews.text: Nice station with a large covered waiting area on both platforms.

This is a very popular station and parking your car can be a problem. The car parks are free but give yourself time to find a parking space. Auto ticket machines as well as a staffed ticket office. Trains depart for Glasgow Queens Street, Stirling and Edinburgh.

As a perimeter station on the Glasgow suburban zone, this station is well used, and is almost at capacity at peak times. Frequent services all day, manned ticket office, limited hours coffee kiosk, and large free car park. Unfortunately Croy needs massive upgrading, it’s not a village station, but a busy commuter mainline station. Car park is frequently full to over capacity, with cars parking in inappropriate places, as well as other drivers forced to start filling up the village streets. Travellers may have to allow 10-15 minutes to find a space. This station requires a multi storey, passenger numbers will continue to increase, inline with more homes being built adjacent. It requires a footbridge at the western end, easing access to the car parks. Waiting room is a match box size for the amount of passengers, and there should be overhead shelter down the length of BOTH platforms for protection from the frequent poor weather. Customer satisfaction and experience could be massively enhanced at this station.
Parking slot, bike stand, local bus service.
My local station. Only issue is the trains don't stop for long, if your a minute out or even 30 seconds you will miss your train!
